title: Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone provides emergency medical aid of unspecified value to Sierra Leone for traffic accident relief
description: On November 7, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated a batch of emergency medical aid and supplies to the Government of Sierra Leone. The purpose of the grant was to facilitate a rescue operation after a major traffic accident occurred on the evening of November 5, 2021. The aid was delivered at Connaught Hospital in Sierra Leone. The monetary value of the grant is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone provides emergency medical aid of unspecified value to Sierra Leone for traffic accident relief

# Description
On November 7, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated a batch of emergency medical aid and supplies to the Government of Sierra Leone. The purpose of the grant was to facilitate a rescue operation after a major traffic accident occurred on the evening of November 5, 2021. The aid was delivered at Connaught Hospital in Sierra Leone. The monetary value of the grant is unknown.
justification: Project is focused on emergency medical aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Emergency medical aid for traffic accident relief, humanitarian focus

title: Chinese Government provides food aid worth USD 2 million to Sierra Leone for Food Aid Tripartite Cooperation Project
description: On July 26, 2021, the Government of China donated food aid to Sierra Leone worth USD 2 million. The aid donated consisted of 2,265 metric tons of rice. The donation was part of the Food Aid Tripartite Cooperation Project, and the donation was made through the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP). The Sierra Leone Ministry of Social Welfare received the donation.  By July 29, 2021, 1,800 out of 2,265 metric tons of rice had been dispersed. The rice was to be used to feed 21,000 households throughout Sierra Leone.
staff_comments: 1. The project name in Chinese is 食援助三方合作项目
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government provides food aid worth USD 2 million to Sierra Leone for Food Aid Tripartite Cooperation Project

# Description
On July 26, 2021, the Government of China donated food aid to Sierra Leone worth USD 2 million. The aid donated consisted of 2,265 metric tons of rice. The donation was part of the Food Aid Tripartite Cooperation Project, and the donation was made through the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP). The Sierra Leone Ministry of Social Welfare received the donation.  By July 29, 2021, 1,800 out of 2,265 metric tons of rice had been dispersed. The rice was to be used to feed 21,000 households throughout Sierra Leone.
justification: Project is focused on food aid and social welfare, with no direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Food aid donation of rice, distributed through WFP to households, focused on food security and social welfare

title: Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone provides Chinese Ambassador Scholarships totaling 470 million Sierra Leonean Leones to 147 students in July 2021
description: On July 22, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone facilitated a ceremony to grant Chinese Ambassador scholarships to 147 Sierra Leonean students. The purpose of the scholarship was to allow students to take online courses provided by Chinese universities and institutions. 125 students received grants of 2 million Sierra Leonean Leones. 22 university students were selected to receive grants of 10 million Sierra Leonean Leones. The total scholarship funds amounted to 470 million Sierra Leonean Leones.  Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhangliang, Minister of Basic Education of Sierra Leone, Deputy Minister of Higher Education, and Chairman of the Sierra-China Friendship Association Kawa were among those who attended the event.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone provides Chinese Ambassador Scholarships totaling 470 million Sierra Leonean Leones to 147 students in July 2021

# Description
On July 22, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone facilitated a ceremony to grant Chinese Ambassador scholarships to 147 Sierra Leonean students. The purpose of the scholarship was to allow students to take online courses provided by Chinese universities and institutions. 125 students received grants of 2 million Sierra Leonean Leones. 22 university students were selected to receive grants of 10 million Sierra Leonean Leones. The total scholarship funds amounted to 470 million Sierra Leonean Leones.  Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhangliang, Minister of Basic Education of Sierra Leone, Deputy Minister of Higher Education, and Chairman of the Sierra-China Friendship Association Kawa were among those who attended the event.
justification: Scholarship program focused on education without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarships for online education, no energy or infrastructure components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million in March 2021
description: In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 900,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone on February 25, 2021. The shipment arrived at the Lungi International Airport in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Its reception was acknowledged with a handover ceremony led by Sierra Leone's Acting Minister of Health, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhanglang. Then, on March 1, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines and 201,600 disposable needles and syringes to the Government of Sierra Leone.  Then, on August 18, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses, 201,600 syringes, 40,000 Novel Coronavirus Nucleic Acid Diagnostic Kits, and 50,000 Novel Coronavirus Antigen Detection Kits to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 300,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Sierra Leone on July 22, 2022. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MOHS) of Sierra Leone held a handover and acceptance ceremony for the donation on August 9, 2022.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the March 2021 donation as $3.6 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million in March 2021

# Description
In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 900,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone on February 25, 2021. The shipment arrived at the Lungi International Airport in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Its reception was acknowledged with a handover ceremony led by Sierra Leone's Acting Minister of Health, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhanglang. Then, on March 1, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines and 201,600 disposable needles and syringes to the Government of Sierra Leone.  Then, on August 18, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses, 201,600 syringes, 40,000 Novel Coronavirus Nucleic Acid Diagnostic Kits, and 50,000 Novel Coronavirus Antigen Detection Kits to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 300,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Sierra Leone on July 22, 2022. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MOHS) of Sierra Leone held a handover and acceptance ceremony for the donation on August 9, 2022.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare through vaccine donations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines, medical supplies, and diagnostic kits for public health purposes

title: Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated food aid of unknown value to Muslim population of Sierra Leone
description: On May 10, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated food aid to the Muslim population of Sierra Leone near the conclusion of Ramadan. The ceremony took place at the Chinese Ambassador’s Residence on Spur Road in Freetown.   The donation consisted of 6.25 tons of rice, 1,250 liters of cooking oil, 2.5 tons of sugar, and 450 kg of salt. The donation was delivered to the United Council of Imams (UCI) to be distributed to the Muslim population throughout Sierra Leone. The monetary value of the grant is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated food aid of unknown value to Muslim population of Sierra Leone

# Description
On May 10, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Sierra Leone donated food aid to the Muslim population of Sierra Leone near the conclusion of Ramadan. The ceremony took place at the Chinese Ambassador’s Residence on Spur Road in Freetown.   The donation consisted of 6.25 tons of rice, 1,250 liters of cooking oil, 2.5 tons of sugar, and 450 kg of salt. The donation was delivered to the United Council of Imams (UCI) to be distributed to the Muslim population throughout Sierra Leone. The monetary value of the grant is unknown.
justification: Project is focused on food aid and social welfare without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Food aid donation consisting of rice, cooking oil, sugar, and salt; distributed through religious organization for social welfare purposes

title: Chinese Government donates 200,000 Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccine doses worth $3.6 million and other supplies in August 2021
description: In 2021 and 2022, the Chinese Government donated approximately 900,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines to the Government of Sierra Leone on February 25, 2021. The shipment arrived at the Lungi International Airport in Freetown, Sierra Leone. Its reception was acknowledged with a handover ceremony led by Sierra Leone's Acting Minister of Health, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Chinese Ambassador Hu Zhanglang. Then, on March 1, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated doses of Sinopharm Covid-19 vaccines and 201,600 disposable needles and syringes to the Government of Sierra Leone.  Then, on August 18, 2021, the Chinese Government delivered another 200,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses, 201,600 syringes, 40,000 Novel Coronavirus Nucleic Acid Diagnostic Kits, and 50,000 Novel Coronavirus Antigen Detection Kits to the Government of Sierra Leone. The Chinese Government delivered an additional 300,000 donated Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine doses to the Government of Sierra Leone on July 22, 2022. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MOHS) of Sierra Leone held a handover and acceptance ceremony for the donation on August 9, 2022.
staff_comments: 1. According to the UNICEF COVID-19 Vaccine Market Dashboard, the price of a single Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine dose is $18 (https://www.oecd.org/officialdocuments/publicdisplaydocumentpdf/?cote=DCD/DAC/STAT(2022)33&docLanguage=En). As such, AidData has estimated the monetary value of the August 2021 donation of vaccines as $3.6 million. This has been added to the value of 90,000 COVID-19 tests in August 2021 ($781,200), estimated by AidData from price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO) for a total transaction amount of $4,381,200.00. For additional details, please see the TUFF Methodology.

title: MOFCOM provided RMB 235 million grant for National Stadium Rehabiliation Project
description: In mid-2021, Sierra Leone faced the national embarrassment of near disqualification from the Africa Cup of Nations for the lack of proper infrastructure to host international sports competitions. Then, on November 5, 2021, China’s Ministry of Commerce issued an RMB 235 million grant to Gansu Construction Investment Holding Group Limited to implement the National Stadium Rehabilitation Project in Sierra Leone. The contract is being fully financed with a grant from the Chinese Government. The purpose of the project is to rehabilitate the National Stadium in Freetown, which was originally built with financial support from the Chinese Government in 1970s. The Chinese Government then implemented eight phases of the National Stadium Technical Cooperation Project between 1996 and 2019 to support the maintenance and rehabilitation of the stadium. The project scope includes the restoration, reinforcement and redecoration of the main stadium, the swimming pool and its ancillary facilities, the renovation of the athletes' hostel, the construction of more than 1,200 square meters of new buildings and facilities, the renewal of drainage, power distribution, ventilation and air conditioning, the installation of a new display screen, artificial turf, synthetic rubber racing track and new lighting equipment, etc. The 572-square-meter ring road surrounding the stadium will also be refurbished. China's Gansu Construction Investment Holding Group Limited is the contractor responsible for project implementation.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
MOFCOM provided RMB 235 million grant for National Stadium Rehabiliation Project

# Description
In mid-2021, Sierra Leone faced the national embarrassment of near disqualification from the Africa Cup of Nations for the lack of proper infrastructure to host international sports competitions. Then, on November 5, 2021, China’s Ministry of Commerce issued an RMB 235 million grant to Gansu Construction Investment Holding Group Limited to implement the National Stadium Rehabilitation Project in Sierra Leone. The contract is being fully financed with a grant from the Chinese Government. The purpose of the project is to rehabilitate the National Stadium in Freetown, which was originally built with financial support from the Chinese Government in 1970s. The Chinese Government then implemented eight phases of the National Stadium Technical Cooperation Project between 1996 and 2019 to support the maintenance and rehabilitation of the stadium. The project scope includes the restoration, reinforcement and redecoration of the main stadium, the swimming pool and its ancillary facilities, the renovation of the athletes' hostel, the construction of more than 1,200 square meters of new buildings and facilities, the renewal of drainage, power distribution, ventilation and air conditioning, the installation of a new display screen, artificial turf, synthetic rubber racing track and new lighting equipment, etc. The 572-square-meter ring road surrounding the stadium will also be refurbished. China's Gansu Construction Investment Holding Group Limited is the contractor responsible for project implementation.
justification: Project focuses on social infrastructure rehabilitation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Stadium rehabilitation project, includes facility upgrades and new construction, funded as a social development grant

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Sierra Leone in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Sierra Leone signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $4,296,000 ($3,382,000 in principal payments and $914,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Sierra Leone. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Sierra Leone secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Sierra Leone in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Sierra Leone signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $4,296,000 ($3,382,000 in principal payments and $914,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement is a financial arrangement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, financial terms and conditions, no specific project implementation

title: China gives government scholarship for 15 Solomon Islander students to study in China in 2021/2022 Academic Year (Linked to Project IDs #89945, #89947)
description: On April 27, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in the Solomon Islands announced 15 2021/2022 Chinese Government Scholarships for Solomon Islanders. Similar scholarships were offered for the 2020/2021 academic year scholarships (see project ID#89945) and the 2022/2023 academic year scholarships (see project ID#89947).  The Ministry of Education and Human Resources Development assisted with dispersing the scholarships, and the Tertiary Education and Skills Authority has help implement the application process for the scholarships. The students who received the 2020/2021 and 2021/2022 may have been delayed in going to China by ongoing pandemic restrictions. On March 20, 2022, over 90 Solomon Islands students left Honiara for China on a chartered Solomon Airlines Airbus. This was the first group of students to travel to China since the beginning of the pandemic. These government scholarships were part of the aid Solomon Islands received from the People's Republic of China after breaking ties with the Republic of China on September 16, 2019. Some of the students who received these scholarships had previously studied in Taipei before finishing their study abroad program in the People's Republic of China.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China gives government scholarship for 15 Solomon Islander students to study in China in 2021/2022 Academic Year (Linked to Project IDs #89945, #89947)

# Description
On April 27, 2021, the Chinese Embassy in the Solomon Islands announced 15 2021/2022 Chinese Government Scholarships for Solomon Islanders. Similar scholarships were offered for the 2020/2021 academic year scholarships (see project ID#89945) and the 2022/2023 academic year scholarships (see project ID#89947).  The Ministry of Education and Human Resources Development assisted with dispersing the scholarships, and the Tertiary Education and Skills Authority has help implement the application process for the scholarships. The students who received the 2020/2021 and 2021/2022 may have been delayed in going to China by ongoing pandemic restrictions. On March 20, 2022, over 90 Solomon Islands students left Honiara for China on a chartered Solomon Airlines Airbus. This was the first group of students to travel to China since the beginning of the pandemic. These government scholarships were part of the aid Solomon Islands received from the People's Republic of China after breaking ties with the Republic of China on September 16, 2019. Some of the students who received these scholarships had previously studied in Taipei before finishing their study abroad program in the People's Republic of China.
justification: Project is focused on education scholarships with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Government scholarships for students, education sector focus, no energy or infrastructure components

title: Chinese Government provides $21.4 million grant — via ETCA — for 2023 Pacific Games Village Project (Linked to Project ID#65020)
description: On September 16, 2019, the Government of the Solomon Islands announced that it was severing diplomatic ties with the Republic of China (‘Taiwan’) and establishing diplomatic ties with the People’s Republic of China (‘China’). In June 2021, the Government of the Solomon Islands and the Government of the People’s Republic of China agreed to undertake a feasibility study for the 2023 Pacific Games Village Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) subsequently committed $21.4 million of grant funding for the project.   Then, on October 14 2021, the Government of the Solomon Islands and the Government of the People’s Republic of China signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an unknown amount of grant funding for an unspecified set of projects.   The purpose of the project is to construct a ‘village’ for the 2023 Pacific Games on the Kukum Campus of Solomon Islands National University (SINU). The construction site covers 10,183 square meters. The village will consist of three dormitories, four floors high, which will provide 216 rooms with the capacity to accommodate 924 athletes during the 2023 Pacific Games. After the 2023 Pacific Games, the village will serve as the dormitory for SINU students. The Chinese side will provide all of the furniture and sanitary facilities for the village. The scope of the project also includes a student activity hall with an equipment storage room next to the dormitories.   Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group is the contractor responsible for project implementation. A project implementation agreement signed on November 12, 2021. Then, on December 30, 2021, the Bureau of International Economic Cooperation of China’s Ministry of Commerce awarded a contract to Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 21, 2022. Construction then began in July 2022.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Solomon Islands National University Dormitory Buildings Project and the SINU Dormitory Project. The Chinese project title is 援所罗门群岛国立大学宿舍楼项目 or 所罗门群岛国立大学宿舍楼项目. 2. Several sources refer to the $21.4 million 2023 Pacific Games Village Project and the $53 million 2023 Pacific Games Stadium Construction Project as a single project worth $74 million.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides $21.4 million grant — via ETCA — for 2023 Pacific Games Village Project (Linked to Project ID#65020)

# Description
On September 16, 2019, the Government of the Solomon Islands announced that it was severing diplomatic ties with the Republic of China (‘Taiwan’) and establishing diplomatic ties with the People’s Republic of China (‘China’). In June 2021, the Government of the Solomon Islands and the Government of the People’s Republic of China agreed to undertake a feasibility study for the 2023 Pacific Games Village Project. China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) subsequently committed $21.4 million of grant funding for the project.   Then, on October 14 2021, the Government of the Solomon Islands and the Government of the People’s Republic of China signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an unknown amount of grant funding for an unspecified set of projects.   The purpose of the project is to construct a ‘village’ for the 2023 Pacific Games on the Kukum Campus of Solomon Islands National University (SINU). The construction site covers 10,183 square meters. The village will consist of three dormitories, four floors high, which will provide 216 rooms with the capacity to accommodate 924 athletes during the 2023 Pacific Games. After the 2023 Pacific Games, the village will serve as the dormitory for SINU students. The Chinese side will provide all of the furniture and sanitary facilities for the village. The scope of the project also includes a student activity hall with an equipment storage room next to the dormitories.   Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group is the contractor responsible for project implementation. A project implementation agreement signed on November 12, 2021. Then, on December 30, 2021, the Bureau of International Economic Cooperation of China’s Ministry of Commerce awarded a contract to Jiangsu Provincial Construction Group. A groundbreaking ceremony took place on June 21, 2022. Construction then began in July 2022.
justification: Project focuses on construction of facilities for a sports event and subsequent student housing, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of dormitories and student activity hall for Pacific Games and university use, no energy or environmental components mentioned
